YANG DI-PERTUAN NEGARA'S SPEECH
Debate on the Address
(Fifth Day)


    Order read for resumption of adjourned debate on Question [8th August, 1960],

    `That the following Address in reply to the speech of the Yang di-Pertuan Negara be agreed to:-

    "We, the Legislative Assembly of the State of Singapore, express our thanks to the Yang di-Pertuan Negara for the speech which he delivered on behalf of the Government at the opening of the present session of this Assembly.".'-(The Prime Minister).

    Question again proposed.

2.31 p.m.

    Mr S. V. Lingam (Aljunied): MrSpeaker, Sir, in my speech yesterday I have given evidence and have concluded that this is a Government for the colonialists. This is a Government for the Shaws and the big compradores. This is not a true P.A.P. Government. I have asked, "Why is the Lee Kuan Yew Government so tied up with the Shaws?" I have also given evidence and concluded that what happened in the City Council was not real integration but "Meadowisation". The

Column: 384

followers of Mr Meadows are now controlling key positions in the City Council. The latest move was to abolish the post of Administrator and replace it with the post of Chief Administrative Officer - only a change of name! Mr P. C. Lim, the most senior local officer in the City Council, who had worked in the City Council for more than 30 years, was demoted and the Director of Social Welfare - a relatively junior officer from the Government - was asked to act as Chief Administrative Officer. Is this not an insult to the City Council local officers? What does the Director of Social Welfare know about City Council matters? It must be remembered that Mr Meadows was also once the Director of Social Welfare. In the City Council, we will still be hearing them talk of integration for many years to come.

    Mr, Speaker, Sir, this is a Government for the Shaws, by Meadows, in the name of the Prime Minister.

    For the last one year, the Lee Kuan Yew Government has done almost nothing for the people except consolidation, reorganisation and preparation to further their own ends. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for National Development talked about Malay welfare. Is he really interested in Malay welfare? Or is he really interested in free overseas trips? He asked his ex-Minister to send him to Indonesia to "study" fishing, but the ex-Minister refused. Several weeks later, there popped up the idea of sending him to Indonesia at great expense to the Government to "study" education. Out of the $800,000 in the 1960 Budget earmarked for primary production, $200,000 had been allotted by the Member for Hong Lim for Malay welfare, and the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for National Development was asked to put up schemes. Despite repeated reminders for many months, he had not even put up one scheme. Instead he spent his time planning how to get free overseas trips. When the Government was first formed, the Member for Hong Lim drew up plans to foster Malay welfare. Within three months, a scheme to build 100

Column: 385

houses in the Jalan Eunos Malay Settlement was started. A scheme to benefit the Malays in the Southern Islands was started and completed. There were other minor projects in the Geylang Serai area to benefit the Malays.

    Sir, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for National Development tried to play on communalism. Let me remind him that whatever the Lee Kuan Yew Government is, it is a Right-wing Government, and it is definitely a Government against communalism. We support the Prime Minister in his strong attitude against all forms of communalism.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for National Development tried to distort the case of the proposed Sembawang Malay Settlement. When the Lim Yew Hock Government was in its last days, it tried to win votes by gazetting several places as proposed Malay Settlements. Some of these places were satisfactory. One of these satisfactory places is Jalan Eunos; and when the P.A.P. Government was formed, the building of the houses there started immediately. An unsatisfactory place was a piece of land in Sembawang for a proposed Malay Settlement. The land had not been acquired and a very high price had been agreed to by the previous Government with the British owners. This land was also full of squatters. The Government intended to find, as a substitute, a piece of State land where there were no squatters. As a matter of policy, the Government should not acquire land where there are many squatters who have to be evicted.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, before his powers were curbed in October 1959, the Member for Hong Lim had launched two big projects to promote Malay welfare, namely, the Southern Islands scheme and the Malay Settlement housing scheme. These were completed within the short space of two to three months. What the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for National Development had done was to call up the ketuas of the Southern Islands, or occasionally to visit them. What for? Mr Speaker, Sir, I understand that he is looking to the Southern Islands in the 1964 general elections. He is more

Column: 386

interested in his own welfare and in his own future. Bukit Timah would not be a safe ward then.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, we have heard during the past six weeks how the Prime Minister consolidates his position with the Assemblymen. The main object is to make them part and parcel of the status quo, a part of the existing social system, and thus resistant to social changes demanded by the overwhelming masses of the people. He has devious methods: brain-washing, free trips (sometimes compulsory free trips), control of Assemblymen's pay. These are a few of the methods employed. The City Councillor Mr Low Por Tuck getting $150 a month is a different social being from the present Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance - he is now getting ten times more income. Five of the Parliamentary Secretaries have compulsory savings. By the end of the five-year term -

    Mr Speaker: Order. All these references to personalities and personal acts of Assembly Members seem to me to be quite irrelevant to the question before the House. I have tried to stop references to personalities. I have indicated definitely that I will stop references to personalities for the rest of this debate. So I ask the Member for Aljunied not to indulge in personalities.

    Mr Lingam: Sir, six motor-cars seized by the Customs were sold to the Parliamentary Secretaries below market prices.

    Mr Speaker: Order. I think the Member for Aljunied must have due regard to the authority of the Chair. The ruling is that all references to personalities must not be indulged in.

    Mr Lingam: Mr Speaker, Sir, this is not the P.A.P. which the masses understood and voted for. We are the true P.A.P. We stand for the aims and ideals of the P.A.P. which the people understood, believed in and voted for. The Lee Kuan Yew Government stands for the Shaws, the compradores and the colonialists.

Column: 387



2.42 p.m.

    Mr John Mammen (Telok Blangah): Mr Speaker, Sir, after 14 months of long silence, the Member for Aljunied has now opened his mouth to utter complete lies in this Assembly.

    Mr Speaker: Order. If the hon. Member is deliberately going to use unparliamentary words which he knows are unparliamentary, then he will not be permitted to speak. "Lie" is an unparliamentary word which should never be used in this Assembly. The hon. Member must withdraw that word.

    Mr John Mammen: Mr Speaker, Sir, I withdraw that word, but may I substitute the words "twisting the facts"?

    Mr Speaker: I will not even accept the words "twisting the facts" in this context. The hon. Member must withdraw those words.

    Mr John Mammen: Sir, I withdraw the words.

    The Member for Aljunied stated that he was not given a chance for the last 14 months to speak in this Assembly. The other accusation was that all the speeches made during the last 14 months by P.A.P. Assemblymen were prepared either by Mr Lee Kuan Yew or Mr George Thomson. But after hearing the speech of the Member for Aljunied yesterday and today, it is now quite clear who is reading from written speeches.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, before I go into the details of the speeches made by the Member for Hong Lim and the Member for Aljunied, I would like to say that they were of a similar nature but, of course, the wording was different. The most important thing the Member for Hong Lim touched on was Malayanisation. Let us go back to the activities in the Ministry of National Development during the last one year. What did the Member for Hong Lim really mean by Malayanisation? For example, let us take the Architects Department. One fine morning, there appeared in the Straits Times and in all the local newspapers an article about Mr Ong Eng Guan's plan of 4,000 units of houses to be built in Singapore. One does not need a technician to give a Press statement. Anybody can call in the Press and put

Column: 388

forward his views. But to carry out the plan of building 4,000 units of houses, you must require efficient and experienced architects. What did the ex-Minister for National Development do on the pretext of Malayanisation? It was "Melbourneisation"! Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Hong Lim is a graduate from Melbourne University. He was of the opinion that one must be a graduate from Melbourne University, otherwise he could not be a true socialist and an anti-colonialist. That is what happened in that department. Why have the local architects left the service of the City Council? It is not because they fear the P.A.P. Government, as put forward by the S.P.A. Members. It is not because they are afraid of their future. It is because they have not graduated from Melbourne University, that they have no future in that department as long as that man is there as the Minister.

    The Member for Aljunied talked about Lui Boon Poh in the City Council. If I am wrong in what I have to say, I hope the Prime Minister or his Parliamentary Secretary will correct me. Mr Speaker, Sir, when the Prime Minister took over the City Council from the Minister for National Development, the whole sewerage system was on the verge of collapse, because we had an "efficient" administrator in Lui Boon Poh. And the ex-Minister for National Development himself admitted in this House Mr Lui's qualifications and experience as an administrator. When the Prime Minister took over the City Council, there was only one engineer left in the service, and he also had tendered his resignation. That was the State of -

    Mr Ong Eng Guan (Hong Lim): Mr Speaker, on a point of clarification.

    Mr Speaker: If the Member will give way.

    Mr John Mammen: I think it is not necessary to clarify.

    Mr Speaker: The Member will not give way.

Column: 389



    Mr John Mammen: And that was the state of affairs left by the so-called socialist and anti-colonialist who is now parted from the P.A.P. because of his "broad" colonial attitude. That was what he had done for the people of Singapore. And in his speech today, the Member for Aljunied boasted of the achievements that he and the ex-Minister for National Development had done - they had done so much for the Malays, they had done so much for the Southern Islanders. Let me remind them: they were expelled from the P.A.P. only recently. Whatever the Member for Hong Lim did was done in his capacity as Minister for National Development, and not as Mr Ong Eng Guan; also he did it as a P.A.P. candidate and a P.A.P. man. So the credit does not go to Ong Eng Guan, but to the P.A.P. He was elected to this Assembly as a P.A.P. candidate in Hong Lim; he was not elected as an Independent candidate. He ran his Ministry as a P.A.P. Minister, and whatever good he did or encouraged was not personal. Maybe he had done something bad, and that is why he is no more with the P.A.P. now.

    Another important point which the Member for Hong Lim as well as the Member for Aljunied brought up was the case of Mr Owen in the City Council. It appears to the people of Singapore that the three so-called socialists went from the Government side to sit in the Opposition to fight Owen's case. It seems that they are the mouthpiece of Mr Owen, and the common man might think that they are obliged to Mr Owen.

    Before I speak on the details of the Yang di-Pertuan Negara's speech, let me go through this pamphlet, Mr Speaker, Sir, on "How to Fight Colonialism". It is a fine heading and can easily get the support of the masses. Everybody wants to fight colonialism; not only Ong Eng Guan or Mr Lingam - I am sorry, Mr Speaker, Sir, it is the hon. Member for Aljunied - but the whole P.A.P. organisation, the working class, the masses are all interested in fighting colonialism. It is a 10-page pamphlet of speeches delivered at the

Column: 390

Badminton Hall on 12th July, 1960. If you go through all this, what way has this so-called anti-colonialist given to the masses to fight colonialism? All these speeches are merely a personal attack on Lee Kuan Yew and Dr Goh Keng Swee, and three expatriate officers - George Thomson, Blades and Meadows. In other words, if you are an anti-colonialist or if you are fighting colonialism, you must first fight George Thomson, Meadows and Blades. And if you kick them out, you are really an anti-colonialist. That is the stand taken by the hon. Member for Hong Lim and the Member for Aljunied. On the last page of the pamphlet, the following conclusions were arrived at the meeting on "How to Fight Colonialism":

    `(1) That the greatest enemy of the people is still colonialism and that all sections of the people must be united to carry on the fight and complete the revolution.'

That is the P.A.P.'s aim. Besides that, these so-called anti-colonialists could not concretely put forward to the public ideas on "How to Fight Colonialism". That is because the Prime Minister gradually and bit by bit took over the departments in the Ministry of National Development and finally the ex-Minister for National Development had nothing in his portfolio. That is the root of this so-called split in the P.A.P.

    Let me turn to the 1959 P.A.P. Election Manifesto. At that time the hon. Member for Aljunied and the Member for Hong Lim were Central Executive Committee members, and they were involved in the drafting of the P.A.P. Manifesto. Let me read from this, Mr Speaker. On page 2:

    `To this purpose, the P.A.P. has recently week by week issued its policy statements on the work that will be carried out in government in the next five years.

    The plans we have laid down in these policy statements are not all ambitious ones. They are realistic plans, based on existing political, social and economic conditions. In drafting these plans, we recognise that an internally self-governing Singapore is not an independent Singapore because control of our foreign affairs and external defence remains in the hands of the British Colonial Office, and so in a sense we are a semi-colony.

    We recognise the severe restriction of land space, a mere 220 square miles, and a present

Column: 391

population of 1½ million, which is still going on at the rate of 65,000 a year. We recognise that our little island has no natural resources and that our economy has for the past 100 years been dependent only on the entrepot trade, and has remained static.

    We recognise the complexities of our multi-racial society and the special problems they pose. It is within this framework that we must work, and within these limitations we must construct our labour basis for a future socialist society.

    The next five years will be critical years of testing those people who believe, like the P.A.P. that socialism can be achieved step by step through peaceful constitutional means.'

This is the P.A.P. Manifesto which was carried out by the Member for Aljunied and the Member for Hong Lim; and they wholeheartedly supported it.

    When this Ong Eng Guan issue was first published in the papers, there was an outburst in Singapore, and the people really did not know what it was all about. Maybe 30,000 or 40,000 people attended the mass rally, and that was the force. But that does not mean that the 40,000 are supporters of the so-called anti-colonialists and supporters of the Members for Hong Lim and Aljunied. The people were quite enthusiastic and wanted to know what were the real differences in the Party and why these Party Executive members, elected on P.A.P. tickets, were suddenly expelled after one year of office. Slowly when the explanations were given, and when everything was over, the people began to realise what the real issue is: whether the P.A.P. has become pro-colonial or whether the so-called anti-colonialists who caused a split in the Party are pro-colonialists. The people of Singapore now begin to realise that the split in the Party was not because the P.A.P. deviated from its basic stand of anti-colonialism, but because of personal grudges. If I may put it bluntly, Mr Speaker, Sir, you cannot have two Prime Ministers in one State - and that was the whole trouble that happened in the Party. We can afford to have only one Prime Minister, and luckily we have an efficient, able and honest Prime Minister to lead the State.

Column: 392



    The P.A.P. is accused of being pro-colonial because it retains George Thomson, Meadows and Blades. The P.A.P. is also accused of being unsocialistic because the Shaws and millionaires are here.

    May I ask: since when did our ex-colleagues become so anti-colonialistic? Since when did they learn that the P.A.P. is pro-colonial? The P.A.P. was formed in Singapore in the year 1954 by the working class. Maybe some of its founders are not in this Assembly, but they are still with the P.A.P. outside, and it is they who began the anti-colonial movement. It is they who supported the P.A.P. from the very beginning up to now and the P.A.P. still has the full support and confidence of the masses in Singapore, especially the trade union movement. The P.A.P. leader, who is now the Prime Minister, attended the Constitutional Talks with the then Chief Minister, and upon his return the Party held many meetings and explained to its members and the people what was the Constitution that was agreed upon. At that time the Member for Hong Lim and the Member for Aljunied were with the Party, and they completely agreed with the Party's stand on this Constitution. If they had not agreed to the Constitution, why did they contest the elections on P.A.P. tickets? Because the P.A.P. categorically stated their stand on the Constitution. This was explained in Petir and Party meetings - that we had to work this Constitution for two or three years, and then we had to go back to London for a new Constitution. And the Party as a whole agreed to it. `If the Member for Hong Lim thinks that the present Constitution is pro-colonial, that the whole administration is pro-colonialist, and that it is not a workable Constitution, then he should have realised, at the time of the election, that he was going to contest the election on a P.A.P. ticket, that is, as a candidate of the Party which agreed to the new Constitution, and which was confident that it would come into power. At that time, it was quite apparent that this was the only Party which was going to get a complete majority. The Member for Hong Lim agreed with it. After working one year

Column: 393

within the Constitution, he suddenly gets a vision that it is not workable because Mr Lee Kuan Yew is there and Dr Goh Keng Swee is there, and they are pro-colonialists, because they are educated in -

    Mr Speaker: The Member must mean the Prime Minister and the Minister for Finance.

    Mr John Mammen: I am sorry, Mr Speaker. Another attack came from the Member for Hong Lim and the Member for Aljunied on trade unions - the cancellation of the federations of trade unions. I will say quite frankly to my friends that the trade union leadership is quite efficient in looking after their own interest. I ask them to leave the trade unions to their leaders The whole membership of the trade unions has complete confidence in its present leaders. So better leave the trade union movement alone and do not interfere with the movement.

    If the Members think that by making an unwarranted attack on the T.U.C. and its leadership they can divide the trade union movement and get their support, then I think they are wasting their time in doing this unhealthy thing. The trade union leadership is here, and they can look after their interest.

    Mr Ong Eng Guan: Mr Speaker, on a point of clarification.

    Mr Speaker: If the Member will give way.

    Mr John Mammen resumed his seat.

    Mr Ong Eng Guan: Mr Speaker, we have never on any occasion attacked the T.U.C. What we did at the Badminton Hall was to expose Mr Woodhull for what he was.

    Mr John Mammen: That is exactly what I was explaining, and the Member for Hong Lim admitted it. Whether it is in the Badminton Hall or in the Assembly or outside, he has admitted it. Whether or not the Member for Hong Lim and two others attacked the T.U.C. and its leadership? He admitted he attacked it. He cannot deny it because it is written in this speech, `T.U.C. and Mr S. Woodhull'.

Column: 394

That is what I would like to remind hon. Members. If by attacking the T.U.C. and its leadership and making an unwarranted attack on them he thinks that he can really become a revolutionary and an anti-colonialist, and he can get some of the union support, then I think politically he is going to be a bankrupt.

    Mr Speaker, since this trouble started in the P.A.P., there may be some in the trade union movement who think that they can also become revolutionaries like the Member for Hong Lim. Let me remind them that the future of this State depends on industrialisation, stable government and a healthy atmosphere in the whole political arena. And if the so-called adventurers and some of their leaders want to create unrest in this country under the pretext of anti-colonialism, then I think the whole trade union should be aware of this fact. We should be prepared to face the situation, and show that we are more responsible and more able, and that we can understand the situation more clearly, even though we - the trade union people - are not graduated from the University in Melbourne. We must show to the world that industrial and economic expansion can be achieved in Singapore with the co-operation and help of the trade union movement and their confidence in the present Government.

    The Member for Aljunied in his speech has said that the Parliamentary Secretary to the ex-Minister for National Development was bringing up communal issues in this House in regard to the political situation in Singapore. But the Member himself indulged in that by bringing up communal issues when he said that the only two people in this Assembly who are interested in the welfare of the Malays are the Member for Hong Lim and the Member for Aljunied. Whatever Government did for the people for the last one year was not done by the P.A.P. Government, but by these two individuals. Where did they get the money from? It is this Government which passed the money, and the Member for Hong Lim acted in the

Column: 395

capacity of the P.A.P. Minister for National Development. How can they come here and tell the public that whatever was done in the Ministry of National Development was done by Ong Eng Guan and not by the P A.P. Government?

    Mr Speaker, Sir, when the Member for Aljunied was attached to the Ministry of National Development, we, the P.A.P. Assemblymen, even at that time considered him, with due respect to him, as part and parcel of the civil service, because, from the information received from our colleagues in the trade union movement - I stand subject to correction, Mr Speaker, Sir - he used to pay periodical or daily visits to the departments and find fault with the civil servants. Yet today in his speech, he says he is the only man who can fight for the local officers, and he is the only man who can give something to the civil servants. But he himself has forgotten that when he was attached to the Ministry of National Development, he was an elected representative of the people and not a civil servant. Today, when he is away from the P.A.P. he himself brings forward the accusation that we are giving trouble, that we are forgetting or neglecting the local officers and civil servants.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, they want to fight colonialism, they want to malayanise, but they are not interested in the whole set-up of the civil service and the technical staff. What they are interested in is this. As long as the three chaps are there - Meadows, Blades and Thomson - then the whole administration is colonial. And if these three people go out, then the Members for Hong Lim and Aljunied are the real anti-colonialists and socialists in this country. But when we say that we are anti-colonial, we categorically state that we are not interested in fighting Europeans. We do not fight them because they are white, they are colonialists. We fight them because of their political ideology. We must know that, especially in dealing

Column: 396

with our colonial masters, we must be tactful and use our brains. If the Member for Hong Lim thinks that, by getting rid of these three chaps, our fight is over, that we are completely independent, and that we are really socialists, then we are far apart. We will never be able to agree with him.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, in the speech of the Yang di-Pertuan Negara, it is stated that the Government is going to build a trade union house and that a committee will be set up to draw up plans. This was wholeheartedly supported by the people when the P.A.P. put this proposal forward during the elections. We hope that with the co-operation of the trade union movement, the building will be completed soon, so that all the unions can utilise the facilities and work for a better and prosperous Singapore.

3.10 p.m.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock (Cairnhill): Mr Speaker, Sir, this is the fifth day of the debate on the address of thanks for the Yang di-Pertuan Negara's speech. an address that does not merit such a lengthy debate. But what has brought about the lengthiness of this debate is because the Honourable the Prime Minister, in moving his motion, has to find it necessary to level an attack on the hon. Member for Hong Lim. And he has thus opened the gate so wide that this Assembly has been treated to, shall we say, the unhappy spectacle of comrades and excomrades quarrelling among themselves, and of exposure after exposure. And that reminds me of a saying, Sir, which we all know. "When blank falls out, honest men will come into their own." Sir, I have not used the word "rogues" because I know that these honourable men are not "rogues". But when something falls out, honest men will come into their own.

    It is typical, Sir, of the P.A.P., not only of the Prime Minister, not only of his Ministerial colleagues, but also of the back-benchers, to rave and rant, to attack unnecessarily the Opposition, and to ridicule the Opposition even before the Opposition has opened its mouth. So the Prime Minister in his speech

Column: 397

said; `What is this I see, the amendments that are proposed by the opposition. What a comic relief.' Sir, what we have been sitting here for five days listening to has been the comic relief provided by the P.A.P. Assemblymen, Ministers and ex-comrades. That is the kind of comic relief we have. Surely, Sir, the Prime Minister must have felt in his heart that some such comic relief would take place in this House, and that is why he used the word. Of course, he has to turn it around and say, `We are providing the comic relief!'

    Sir, the Members on the other side said that we had not pronounced any world-shaking events. We have treated the world-shaking pronouncement of the Prime Minister with little concern. Sir, I will touch on that in due course. But they, Sir, in all their speeches, have not even accepted in their own minds, that there was such a world-shaking statement made by the Prime Minister. They went into ridicule, jibes, and criticisms. They even went so far as to suggest that all the ills that they have perpetrated during the past 14 months are the ills they inherited from the past Government. And yet the Member for Hong Lim said that all the good things, all the buildings that they claimed they had built, were built by the past Government. I say, Sir, in this House: let the people judge the Government not by what the previous Government did or did not do.
